segments.text: My first contact with Walter Monk was before, was in 1937, when he was an undergraduate at Caltech.
You got to see him going?
Sure had.
He came down here in the summertime, that summer.
I think he basically came down here because he was interested in the girl named Shlump Sanders, the granddaughter of Ellen Browning Scripps' lawyer, Jacob Harper.
Anyhow, he was here, and he worked at Scripps.
And we spent several days together sitting in a rowboat about half a mile off the end of our pier measuring currents.
We had a contraption that you could lower to the bottom.
It would sit on the bottom and measure currents there.
And we could also measure them in the water coming up to the surface.
And we did this by hand over and over and over again for several days.
And he came back.
He's been coming back ever since.
He was one of our first summer fellows at Scripps.
He turned out so successfully that they've been running this summer fellowship program for the last 40 years.
I don't think they've ever found anybody quite his equal.
In fact, I don't know of anybody who ever became an oceanographer that way, besides Walter.
But maybe once in 40 years is enough.
Well, exactly how did Operation Crossroads evolve?
The first I heard of it was when two naval captains, I was a commander in the Bureau of Ships then, two naval captains, one of whom was Horatio Rivera,
You may have heard of him.
He was later deputy chief of naval operations, commander of NATO forces in southern Europe, later ambassador to Spain.
He was a little man from Puerto Rico, about five feet, two inches high, and one of the brightest men I ever saw in my life.
A captain named Ashworth, Fred Ashworth, who was an aviator, called me into their office and asked me to help pick out a site for an atomic bomb test, a test of atomic bombs against naval ships.
So Mary Sears and I got together, and they were thinking about Bikini already.
in the Marshall Islands in general, we recommended a bikini.
But they'd already been thinking of making a test.
You may not remember it if you're too young, but in those days, there was a great deal of question about whether, with the existence of atomic bombs, naval ships were of any use anymore.
So the problem of just how vulnerable ships were to them was an important subject.
And we, of course, had lots of ships.
We had the greatest Navy that the world had ever dreamed of, let alone seen.
Many more ships than we had possibly ever used again.
And so they
They appointed Admiral W.H.P.
Blandy as commander of his task force, and Deke Parson as the technical officer in charge.
Both these officers were members of what the Navy has called a gun club.
They were ordnance officers.
Although Blandy had actually had command
Task Force in the city.
They were both service officers, service ship officers.
But I guess Parsons was actually a specialist, but not in line of command.
He was a specialist in ordnance.
He had been involved right from the beginning at Los Alamos and elsewhere in the development of the Manhattan Project.
And he was the bombardier on one of the two atomic bomb drops in Japan.
And they assembled a staff, a big staff.
worked very closely with Los Alamos, who were making the bomb.
They were really devices.
One of them was a device, and the other was an actual weapon.
And one of the things that we thought had to be known was what would be the effect of the explosion and the radioactivity on the atoll.

So we decided that we'd make an ecological, essentially an ecological base study to find out what the conditions were before they, find out as much as we could about what was there and what things were like before any radioactive had been released and before there was any explosion.
And so we sent out an old ship, the Bowditch,
to do with a whole group of scientists, various kinds of scientists, geologists, botanists, fish people, people to study all the different kinds of living things that were there.
One of the people was Harry Ladd from the Geological Survey.
Another was a man named Taylor from the University of Michigan.
William Randolph Taylor was a great taxonomic botanist.
Jack Marr was there for the fishing, for the fish part of it.
Quite a few fish people.
We had experimental fishermen as well as fish taxonomists.
And they spent about six months making a profile of what Bikini Atoll would like.
And the surrounding waters where Ken Emery was there did a lot of work on the bottom.
I guess Bill Bonarcs was there.
There were three people from Woods Hole looking at the water and looking at the diffusion of the water.
It was a group of people from a lot of different institutions.
One of the people was Marsden Sargent from SREPS, who was my assistant in the Bureau of Ships.
And he was made the project officer.
And they had this old hydrographic survey ship that was sent out there and spent about six months there, long in advance of the arrival of the task force, finding out what the biology was like.
Then we had other oceanographic things that we, responsibilities that we had were, one, to measure the waves.
That was perhaps the most important thing.
We thought there might be some very big waves, particularly from the underwater test.
And we also had a group of destroyers to measure the radioactivity in the water outside the atoll to try to follow the fallout.
I'm not sure they were destroyed.
I think they were EPCER.
They were smaller than the destroyer, about six of them.
John Lyman was in charge of that part of it.
And then we had I guess everything was really related to the waves, one way or the other.
But we did a lot of different things.
We put up photographic towers 100 feet high.
put the cameras on them, it would be started automatically.
And still cameras, essentially, would take very good pictures of what happened, the sequence of events.
We had bottom-mounted wave meters, which we called turtles.
They were developed by Alan Vines and his whole.
Jeff Holder had a very simple system.
He put up sticks on the beach, poles on the beach,
with a series of tin cans nailed at different heights above the beach.
And those cans that were filled with water would show how high the wave was at that point, you see.
Another man who was not part of our group, but who was the same ingenious kind of a person was Bill Penney, who later became Lord Penney, in charge of the British atomic weapons establishment.
He had tin cans that were closed.
You could measure the blast by seeing how much these were bent or dented, how much they were squeezed together.
Almost as ingenious as Jeff's idea of these open tin cans that would show the wave height.
a whole ship that was devoted to these oceanographic measurements.
John Isaacs was very much involved with the photography.
Gifford Ewing and Walter Monk were involved with the measurements of the dispersion or diffusion of the radioactivity inside the atoll.
We had a lot of measurements, ways of measuring radioactivity inside the atoll.
I think Ted Folsom was involved with this, too.
I'm not quite sure whether he was or not, but I think so.
John Isaacs can tell you a lot about that.
He had all sorts of funny experiences.
We were putting up these wave measuring devices and dispersion measuring devices.
all over the atoll.
It was about 20 miles long, the lagoon, I mean, inside the atoll.
And they had a series of landing craft to carry them around and to move from one end of the atoll to the other.
These were not LC VMs.
They were one size larger.
They were essentially about 50 foot long, 60 foot long, and quite beamy, sort of barges.
And it was typical.
Those were the days when the Navy was its absolute navy.
And most of the enlisted men there were guys who had been paroled or sentenced to jail or the Navy's equivalent of jail for quite a long time.
But if they'd go out to Bikini, they'd be paroled, put on probation.
And it was typical.
crews of these damn landing craft would get up to the far end of the lagoon and say, well, we think our discharge papers have arrived.
We better go back.
And the only guys that were there with them were the civilians, the scientists.
They didn't pay any attention to them.
They had to pay very little attention to them.
They had to go back and by God, their discharge papers had arrived.
And you had to get another crew and start all over again.
We had also quite a bit of experimental work in advance of it, particularly the underwater test.

Because the underwater test was, there had been a theory developed in the last part of the war, which was given a good deal of credence by Winston Churchill, that he thought it was true that you could make a huge wave if you made an explosion at the right, big enough explosion at the right depth underwater.
The theory more or less wore this out.
that this wave would travel a very long way and would be a kind of a weapon, causing very considerable amounts of damage at great distances.
This underwater explosion was one way of testing this out.
And in order to get some idea of the magnitude and of the phenomenology, Mike O'Brien, who was then dean
School of Engineering at Berkeley, College of Engineering at Berkeley, organized a series of tests, test explosions, which they photographed with high-speed photography.
And we, afterwards, we looked back on those tests and we saw something
which really occurred as a painting.
That was something called the Bay Surge.
Have you ever heard of the Bay Surge?
The Bay Surge is the most frightening thing I ever saw in my life.
First time to see it.
It was what looked like a wall of solid water, several hundred feet high, moving very rapidly out from the point of the explosion.
But after it got about half a mile out, it stopped.
and lifted from the surface.
And then there was a huge rain.
And what it was was essentially a very dense cloud.
It was a density current.
What happened was that the underwater explosion shot a column of water and air, a huge pillar, about half a mile across, up into the air.
And then this thing settled down again.
And it was essentially a mist or a cloud.
But it was heavier than air because there was so much water in it.
So it came down like this and then spread out like this.
Then as enough water dropped out of the thing, it was hot.
Therefore, the air was able to lift above the surface of the base surge after about something like 30 seconds.
just lifted off the water.
It turned out not to be a wave at all.
And there were waves in addition, and we were able to measure the waves.
The waves were like 10 feet high or 15 feet high.
This thing was, to begin with, a couple hundred feet high.
This looked terrible.
It moved very, very rapidly.
It was what we call a density curve, coming out like that.
This was a very interesting phenomenon, which we never would have really been able
understand or even to record if it hadn't been for the enormous amount of work that John Isaacs and other guys did in setting up these photographic towers and the photographic systems.
A year later, I organized something called a re-survey of Bikini.
This was after I was in ONR.
The re-survey went back there with a much smaller task force to see what had happened, what was it like a year later.
We had a group of biologists and radiochemists there.
That was one of the hardest jobs I ever did in my life, was organizing the scientific part of that re-survey.
Nobody wanted to be involved.
But there were lots of radiochemists.
And I managed to get Charlie Coriel, who later became a professor of chemistry at MIT.
I somehow got, I guess I knew him before the war.
I knew him at UCLA.
And he'd been involved with the radiochemistry business all during the war.
And he managed to recruit a group of good radiochemists to go out there to work on this problem.
If it hadn't been for him, I would have been sunk.
I used to stay up 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning calling people all over the country, trying to get them to go out on this resurvey at Bikini.
This was in 1947.
And it worked out very well.
The most important outcome, however, scientifically, was the drilling that we did on Bikini Atoll.
We got an oil well drilling company
contract to drill a hole in the reef.
Because the results we got in the previous year from our seismic work indicated that the limestone was several thousand feet thick.
The reef was several thousand feet thick.
And that maybe at a depth of a mile or more, you finally came to basalt.
This is one of the great, at that time, one of the great unsolved questions was, what was the origin of coral reefs?
Darwin had had the idea long ago, 150 years ago, 250 years ago now, that coral reefs were sunken volcanoes.
And then as the volcano sank, the coral reef built up.
And at first, you had a volcano here with a fringing reef around it.
As the volcano sank, the reef moved out and became a barrier reef.
And as the volcano sank still more, you had nothing except the reef and the lagoon in the middle.
And there were other people who said this was just nonsense.
The reefs were formed during the Pleistocene.
And so it was very important.
very important, thought to be a very important thing to do to find out just what they were like.
And it turns out, it turns out that they were at least Bikini, and later Eniwetok, and other ones that have been studied since, that they're all flat-topped seamounts where the
The mountain was planed off at sea level with a pile of volcanic ash, in other words, lava, cut off by waves at sea level.
And the coral grew around the edges of these things.
And then they sank.
And as they sank, the coral, if they sank slowly enough, the coral could keep up and eventually ended up with an atoll.
The lagoon in an atoll, however it is a Pleistocene phenomenon, when the sea level was about 200 feet lower than it is now, these things were all planed off.

And so the islands around the edges of the atoll, I mean the atoll itself, the islands around the lagoon, are all not more than a million years old, formed during the Pleistocene on a platform planed off during the Pleistocene, which is the bottom of the lagoon, the deepest part of the lagoon.
But underneath that, there's a bone pile 6,000 feet thick, or 4,000 to 6,000 feet thick, of the remains of coral and coralline algae, which grew on a submerged volcanic platform.
And you find lots of things called geos, or flat top seamounts, which sank too fast and which have a little bit of coral on them.
but not very much.
And they're covered mostly with manganese, crusts of manganese, with occasional shallow water fossils, enough so you can tell their age and that they were in shallow water when they were planed off.
And that was one of the discoveries we made during our mid-Pacific expedition.
These sea mounts, far from being a billion or two billion years old, were about 100 million years old.
of Cretaceous age.
And we found that by finding fossils that were shallow water fossils, now at depths of 6,000 feet, which were Cretaceous fossils.
But the first part of this study was the seismic work during Operation Crossroads.
But in the follow-up?
In the follow-up, in the bikini resurvey.
Should we have another Bikini test, by the way, now that the bombs are more powerful?
Well, we have had a whole series of the hydrogen bomb tests on Bikini and on the Weetalk.
They tested all the big thermonuclear weapons there.
But you're thinking about a test against ships?
Yes.
Well, that's very hard to do.
We did have a test of an underwater atomic weapon down here off Mexico.
We lowered the weapon to about 3,000 feet and exploded it.
But nobody's ever, as far as I know, nobody's ever exploded a thermonuclear device underwater.
I may be wrong about that.
In any case, they're so big that if you explode one
lagoon like Bikini Lagoon.
You'd blow the water out of the lagoon.
I only have one other question about this part of your career I want to ask you.
Why not a career in the Navy?
Did you ever consider a career in the Navy?
Yes, I did.
But after World War II, not before World War II.
But I really wanted to go back to Scripps.
The only reason for considering a career in the Navy was that they didn't really want me back at Scripps very much.
And a lot of guys didn't.
fairly complex story, but Carl Eckhardt and Harold Sverdrup were just bound and determined that I could be Sverdrup's successor as director of the Scripps Institution.
And there were a lot of, there were several other people on the faculty who didn't think this was a good idea at all, including Fran Shepherd and Carl Hubbs of Fisheries.
They had different reasons.
My analysis would be that Hubbs thought we ought to have a biologist.
Not a military man, not a naval man.
All things not a naval man.
Shepard's opposition was basically because we hadn't gotten along very well when he had this project, GSA project.
He's really not very bright.
If Lyman Spitzer has an IQ 40 points higher than mine, my IQ is considerably higher than Francis Shepherd's.
Shepherd's got other qualities, including indefatigable curiosity and enormous energy.
But how'd it all be smart?
And that's kind of hard to work with a much younger man who's a lot smarter than you are.
You don't have a generous spirit.
So in any case,
They were opposed to my being director.
And finally a compromise was hit on that was that Carl Eckhart should become director.
So he was director for two years.
Was that?
OK, that makes sense.
And he asked me to come back as an associate director, which I did.
And I was promoted to the professorship at the same time.
I'm the only guy who ever went from being an instructor to being a professor without any intermediate steps.
I was an instructor when I went into the Navy and came back here as a professor.
And as associate director.
My impression is you were carried on the faculty listing of Scripps Institution the whole time you were the Navy.
That's right.
Sure.
They may have even promoted me in absentia.
I'm not quite sure about that.
